0	0	1	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	1	0	0	1	0	4	1	0	287	0	1	0	1	In addition to a small brush, Robert uses swabs of cotton to clean the surface of the sculpture. They can be made any size, big or small. Micropoint cotton swabs (originally designed for cleaning electronics) are also used for detailed cleaning.#NGAconservationpic.twitter.com/xrpHi5acUi
0	0	1	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	1	0	0	1	0	3	0	0	300	0	1	0	1	pH adjusted deionized water (in the bottle) is used to clean grime and handle residues from the marble surface. Stone can be damaged by acidic solutions, so the pH is raised (making it more alkaline) to protect the marble. The meter is used to check the solution's pH level.pic.twitter.com/hFJZWhVPnN
0	0	1	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	1	0	0	0	1	0	3	1	0	203	0	1	0	1	What's up with the tape? The ferrule (the metal band that connects the bristles to the handle) is covered in tape to protect the sculpture from being scratched. #NGAconservationpic.twitter.com/2rLJOFPEsG

0	1	16	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	0	0	1	0	4	0	0	305	0	0	0	1	Finally, artists painted the areas of “encarnación,” or flesh tone. A layer of lead white paint and coating of animal glue gave the oil paint a high polish. They then painted the skin, facial details, and hair, with pink glazes added to areas such as cheeks, knees, and knuckles.pic.twitter.com/MojZJwUu0j
0	2	24	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	0	0	0	1	0	3	0	0	301	0	1	0	1	Artists also used a technique known as “estofado,” in which gold was brushed with thin layers of egg tempera paint. After the paint dried, a patterned design was sketched freehand or transferred from a template. Then, paint was carefully scraped away to reveal the gold leaf.pic.twitter.com/mhbm1BNUtP
0	1	10	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	1	0	0	0	4	0	0	280	0	1	0	1	Next came the gold. Bole was dampened with water to soften the glue, and individual leaves of gold were floated on the surface using a gilder’s brush. Gold was gently tapped to expel any air bubbles and after drying, was polished with a burnishing stone.pic.twitter.com/u7NCnFTRt7
0	1	6	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	0	0	0	0	3	0	0	289	0	1	0	1	Step 3: gilding and painting. Wood was first coated with two layers of gesso (left), a substance made of animal glue mixed with plaster. On top of the gesso, a workshop assistant applied layers of bole (right), consisting of iron-rich clay mixed with animal glue.pic.twitter.com/u8IrPANFwq
0	1	11	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	0	0	1	0	4	0	0	285	0	1	0	1	Cloths soaked in glue were also used to cover joins. As wood shrank and expanded with differences in temperature and humidity, the cloth prevented pieces from shifting out of place. Some of the figures’ garments were also fashioned from cloths soaked in glue.pic.twitter.com/ZrHjQW4dAy
0	1	9	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	0	0	0	0	4	0	0	299	0	1	0	1	Step 2: carving and joining. Each sculpture on the "retablo" was carved from numerous pieces of wood that were then joined together with dowels. This unusual technique allowed for expressive and dramatic designs that were not limited by the shape of a single block of wood.pic.twitter.com/ifZKwOUuhH
0	3	8	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	1	1	1	0	3	1	0	282	0	1	0	1	Step 1: create a “muestra rasguñada,” or master design. Although no plan survives for the “retablo mayor” he made for the Church of San Benito el Real in Valladolid (seen in this reconstruction), a document from 1527 required #AlonsoBerruguete to make one.pic.twitter.com/6D4FHUFhAw

0	4	18	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	1	0	1	1	0	1	0	3	1	0	297	0	1	0	1	Intense magnification of the Putto also revealed that #Verrocchio added wool fibers to his clay. Wool remnants would have been readily available in Florence, a city with a thriving textile industry, and helped strengthen the sculpture, allowing it to survive to this day!pic.twitter.com/cF2ifnuBcG
0	9	22	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	1	1	0	0	0	4	1	0	249	0	1	0	1	An x-ray revealed a malleable iron skeleton of rods, nails, and twisted wires inside #Verrocchio's "Putto Poised on a Globe." This would have allowed the sculptor to move the figures limbs as he sculpted it out of wet clay.pic.twitter.com/xXV1sS8lnu
0	2	9	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	1	0	0	1	0	3	1	0	296	0	1	0	1	#Verrocchio's "Putto Poised on a Globe” (c. 1480) is made of fragile “terra cruda,” which is raw, unbaked clay. The Putto is riddled with fine cracks which were formed as its clay air-dried and also as it was handled over time. Its survival for 500+ years is remarkable.pic.twitter.com/nteG88LDWu

They found that: - Women donors make up 48% of total donors historically - Of women donors, 53% were individuals and 36% were couples - Of the 42,415 works given by women, 26,433 are prints and 8,197 are drawingspic.twitter.com/oR29rlRF3V

After immigrating to America in 1856, Gardner was the head of Matthew Brady's DC studio before establishing his own. In 1866, he published "Gardner's Photographic Sketch Book of the War." #TheEyeoftheSunpic.twitter.com/zhfOWBsLSw

There, he met artists like Michelangelo and found success as a painter. The exhibition includes one of the few surviving paintings from this time—”Salome” (c. 1514–1517), on loan from the @UffiziGalleries.pic.twitter.com/DVzKKDEHxq

0	6	20	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	0	1	0	1	0	4	1	0	302	0	1	0	1	#IMPei carried over many of the West Building's elements: marble from the same quarries, natural light, an entrance on the same axis, and a center place for visitors to gather. He also physically connected them with an underground concourse and street-level cobblestone plaza.pic.twitter.com/HYF732yexI
0	0	9	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	1	1	0	1	0	5	1	0	299	0	0	0	1	Architect #IMPei was selected to design the East Building in 1967. Pei embraced the unusual trapezoidal plot of land, designing a building divided into 2 triangles:  An isosceles for galleries and public functions  A smaller right one for an administrative and study centerpic.twitter.com/uPyRAHxFDu
0	0	7	1	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	0	1	0	0	0	3	0	0	274	0	0	0	1	While it may look very traditional, the West Building was designed using the most modern technology at the time. The exterior is made of pale pink Tennessee marble, while the foundations and 1st floor were formed of concrete with a steel framework.pic.twitter.com/DslS5KvyLr
0	0	4	2	243000	ngadc	0	evening	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	3	0	0	305	0	1	0	1	Intimate, interconnected galleries were designed off of these larger spaces, so that a visitor could start in one room and continue without backtracking. Pope also recognized the importance of natural light, and designed skylights that cover virtually the entire three-acre roof.pic.twitter.com/uNRWsoKeop

0	2	21	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	0	0	0	0	4	1	0	301	0	1	0	1	After falling out of favor by the early 19th century, artists like Jean-François Millet helped revive the medium, while Degas exploited pastel’s potential, experimenting with a wide range of wet and dry techniques and sometimes combining pastels with printmaking. #NGAPastelspic.twitter.com/NoQXYKj1xk
0	3	19	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	1	1	1	0	3	1	0	289	0	1	0	1	Pastel “painting” was popularized across Europe in the 18th century by Rosalba Carriera. Rising to celebrity status, Carriera made portraits of Grand Tourists visiting Venice, which the young aristocrats would bring home as souvenirs of their travels. #NGAPastelspic.twitter.com/jbJkVe8Cg3
0	2	13	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	1	1	0	1	0	4	1	0	288	0	1	0	1	The Gallery is lucky to have a broad collection of pastels, with examples from nearly every major period of the medium's history, ranging from this "Portrait of a Man Wearing a Hat with a Medallion" (1520/1540) to G. Daniel Massad's "Breach" (2009). #NGAPastels.pic.twitter.com/PcbGS0rcUm
0	7	19	1	243000	ngadc	0	afternoon	0	0	0	0	0	1	0	3	1	0	287	0	1	0	1	Pastels are made from a paste of pigment, white opaque filler, and binder, shaped into sticks and dried. The powdery medium does not adhere securely to paper or canvas, making pastels extremely fragile and exhibitions of pastel works like #NGAPastels very rare.pic.twitter.com/KCVSdrTihL
